Executive Summary

The BEI Hawaii operates 6 warehouses statewide which store fertilize, pesticide, agricultural and industrial chemicals.   In order to comply with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) and protect public safety and environment, BEI Hawaii developed site specific Risk Management Plan (RMP) for BEI Hawaii?s warehouses that are regulated under risk management program. 

The Goal of a Risk Management program is to prevent serious chemical accidents that could cause harm to the public and the environment and to reduce the potential impact of the accidental release. 
TThis Risk Management Plan (RMP) is prepared for Kauai facility of BEI Hawaii, formerly know as Brewer Environmental Industries.  This facility store fertilizer, pesticides, and agricultural and industrial chemicals.  BEI Hawaii developed this site specific Risk Management Plans for BEI Hawaii?s facility that are regulated under risk management program to comply with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention requirements: Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) and to protect public safety and environment.  The goal of our risk management program is to prevent serious chemical accidents that could cause harm to our employees, the publics, and the environment and to reduce the potential impact of the accidental release.

This RMP consists of four chapters.  Chapter 1, Management, introduces the plans and describes the facility operations, management and responsibilities.  Chapter 2, Hazardous Assessment, provides hazard release consequences and impact in worst case and alternative scenario, and five-year accident history of Chlorine.  Chapter 3, Prevention Program, provides some safety information, hazard analysis, operation procedures, and prevention procedures.  Chapter 4, Summary of Emergency Response program

Accidental Release Prevention an

d Emergency Response Policies
BEI Hawaii believes in a clean and safe environment and is dedicated to meet all applicable environmental standards in the operation of its businesses and services.  BEI Hawaii has established comprehensive policies and procedures for the operations of its facilities.  The policy is a commitment to environmental compliance that assigns the responsibility of implementing the policy to Chief Executive Officer of the company, or designated individual or individuals to ensure compliance.  The purpose of the policy is to provide employees with a safe and healthy working environment, and to protect the environmental from pollutions.

Preservation of the environment is a commitment that must be shared by all employees.  Employees shall promptly report suspected violations of environmental laws, regulations or permits to their supervisor who shall take immediate action to verify the report and, If confirmed, stop the violation and take remedial or other appropriate action.  The incident shall be promptly reported to BEI Hawaii?s Regulatory Compliance Manager, who will assist in making any necessary reports to regulatory agencies.

Overall approach to chemical safety begins with the premise that safety is everyone?s responsibility and working safely is a condition of employment. Workplace hazards are minimized through preventive measures such as facility and equipment design, purchase of less hazardous products and development of standard operating procedures. Control measures include facility inspections to discover potential problems, employee reports of hazardous conditions, training and a safety award program.   

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 
The BEI HAWAII ? Kauai facility is located at 3-1480 Kaumualii Highway, Luhui, Kauai Island.   The facility stores pesticides, fertilizers and industrial chemicals.  The products are warehoused at the facility and distributed to various locations throughout the Kauai Island.  The regulated

substance handled at this storage/distribution facility is chlorine.  Chlorine is received in 150-lb and 1-ton Department of Transportation (DOT) approved cylinders.  BEI HAWAII receives chlorine from a chemical supplier and distributor located on the west coast.  The chlorine supplier is responsible for container inspection and maintenance.  On average, the BEI HAWAII facility stores approximately 60,000 lbs chlorine (this value can increase to about 116,000 lbs chlorine depending on shipping schedules).  Because bulk sales are made directly to customers, access to the facility is not restricted.

Release Scenarios
Two release scenarios (worst case scenario and alternative scenario) have been assessed for chlorine.
    a) Worst Case scenario
The release scenario is the total release of the largest quantity of the regulated chemical from a one-ton cylinder.  There is no passive mitigation and the release occurs under the worst weather conditions.

    b) Alternative Scenario
The alternative scenario is most likely to occur than the worst case, and there is an active mitigation measure that can limit the amount of release.  

In both cases the OCA Guidance was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Steps
The facility complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management rule.  A process safety management plan was written for the facility that includes all of the required elements.  Since the process is storage only, the practices important to the prevention program are the proper storage and handling of the chlorine.  Dry, isolated and fireproof storage spaces are provided where the temperature of the vicinity of the cylinders never reaches 140 degrees Fahrenheit.  Proper loading and unloading of cylinders from trucks are very important to prevent cylinders from falling and cause possible damage to the valve area.  Training and careful work practices are the key to preventing accidental damage to the c

ylinders.

Five-Year Accident History
The facility has not experienced any accidents during the past five years.  This is understandable because the process is mainly storage only with minimal using of the chlorine on site.

Emergency Response Program 
The BEI HAWAII ? Kauai facility is classified as a non-responding facility.  As such, BEI HAWAII has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employee/community safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response with an in-house response team.  The BEI HAWAII - Kauai Facility has developed its own procedures as outlined in the BEI HAWAII Safety and Health Program incorporating information from Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 64, Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities.  BEI HAWAII has coordinated response to incidents with the Kauai Fire Department Hazmat Team.  Operators are capable, however, of responding to incidental releases such as routine tightening of a valve, for example. 

BEI HAWAII ? Kauai facility personnel will only perform defensive mitigation measures (i.e., secure areas, initiate water spray, etc.,) to limit the release until a response team arrives to establish the incident command.  We have discussed this program with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Kauai Fire Department.  In addition, BEI HAWAII has arranged with local response contractors to deal with potential releases at the facility.  


Planned change to improve safety
There are no current plans to change storage practices at this facility. Chlorine use for swimming pools and sewage treatment is anticipated to diminish over the next few years as new disinfections methods are employed.  BEI HAWAII has already experienced reduced levels of chlorine at its facilities as a result of its efforts to educate and switch customers from chlorine gas to sodium hypochlorite
